trial_identification.studytitle: The use of honey in the treatment of molluscum contagiosum in children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of topical honey application on molluscum contagiosum skin lesions

interventions.interventions: Manuka honey applied topically to the skin lesions and covered with a transparent adhesive dressing, changed every two days, for a total duration of 4 weeks
interventions.comparator: There is no control group, a baseline comparison will be made.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Assessment of response to treatment based on de-identified photographs of the pre-selected target treatment area by a blinded reviewer - the response will be graded as "complete response", "partial response" or "no response".

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Parent/caregiver assessment of response after treatment.
Parent/caregiver assessment of treatment acceptability after treatment.
Assessment of compliance with dressing changes.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. 3-16 years old 2. Presenting to the General practitioner with classic uncomplicated molluscum contagiosum skin lesions of mild-moderate severity 3. Parent/caregiver agrees to be compliant with application of the honey dressings
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Study doctor decision that the patient is not suitable for the study 2. Immunocompromised child 3. Presence of co-existing eczema or other skin disorders 4. Children with known food allergies or history of allergy to bees or honey products

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a viral infection of the skin most common on the body, arms, and legs. About one in six children aged one to ten years are infected at some time with MC. Individual lesions go away on their own but only after 6 months to 5 years. Treatment is not always necessary but may be sought for a variety of reasons such as bleeding, secondary infections, itching and discomfort, or for social reasons. There are several treatments, but they are not very effective and can also be painful and expensive. There is some evidence that manuka honey may be beneficial although it has never been studied in this condition before. This study aims to investigate the efficacy of topical manuka honey treatment with simple observation in a group of children with MC
